comment.author: 32162360@N00

Building progress description (5/6/1903) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14525460 Successful trials (10/9/1903) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14531767 Open for traffic (14/9/1903) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14549616

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/22616984@N07] Thanks for that link, a good description of the counterweight system.

From (the link above) Wikipedia:

"...From the beginning of the twentieth century, Sydney's electric tram system extended down to the Darling Street wharf and connected with the ferries. The tramway operated until 1954.[1] As the road next to the wharf had a grade of 1 in 8.25, a unique counterweight dummy system was installed under the road surface to help push trams up the hill. An underground counterweight system was connected by cable to a cable tram grip dummy on the track on the surface. A tram descending would push the grip dummy ahead of it (which raised the counterweight). On the return journey, the grip dummy would give the tram a helpful push. The mechanism was removed to the Sydney Tramway Museum when the tramway was removed..."

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Great detective work again! We'll add a c.1903 date above. From the article of 5/6/1903 the construction work carried out by Clyde Engineering Company Limited.

I also replaced this with a larger version to see the poster - is it "Old Judge"  ?

AB

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Old Judge Cigarettes: "They CHARM by their FRAGRANCE, and SATISFY on account of their purity." - The Sydney Morning Herald, Saturday 16 March 1907, p. 11. Disclaimer! www.quitnow.info.au/

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: (Ha ha pellethefunnypoet) [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Thanks for the larger resolution - it is "Old Judge", evidently another type of tobacco imported by the America Tobacco Company - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goodwin_%26_Company. It was the art nouveau typeface (like Coca-Cola and The Bulletin) which made me suspicious of the 1892 date in the good book. I can also see "Pears Soap" and "Lowes".

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: This is a Charles Kerry & Co. photo. "43-47" is its catalogue number in the Tyrrell Collection. See Charles Kerry's Federation Australia by David P. Millar (Darlinghurst : David Ell Press, 1981), p. 65.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Hmmm, interesting. Caused me to find this in the Powerhouse Museum Clyde Engineering collection - a photo of the very odd looking counterweight dummy car - from.ph/376085 . The dummy looks new, so the image must also be 1903.

comment.author: 56799987@N04
comment._content:
The story of gettting trams down to Darling Street Wharf was more complex than just the counterweight. I identified 12 other plans and proposals in an article in Trolley Wire November 2003. The counterweight was approved in Feb 1903 and even afterwards there was a finacila dispute between its engineer and the government
Regards
Duncan

comment.author: 93255176@N07
comment._content: I am desperate for a dimensioned drawing/sketch so that I can build a copy for use on my own tramway.... I'll swap a G scale trolley ear for any worth while info... trevs-tramway.blogspot.com.au/

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/93255176@N07] @ Tramcar Trev2 - the PowerHouse Museum has heaps of Clyde Engineering stuff - from.ph/376085 . Try them? [Darn it! I always wanted a "G scale trolley ear" !]

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content: Lanyon Valley Branch line ?

comment.author: 93255176@N07
comment._content:
Tryed them with nil return for what I want. Ok I did want a dimensioned sketch but have since found a few photos in private collections and on line and I found a few B&W shots taken when this car was built ( photographed at Clyde engineering) and as I'm building it as new this is good enough for me to scale it to my size and get the proportions.... It gets better a few weeks ago I was a guest of the Light Rail and got the name of an original Sydney tram conductor who still works casual shifts he in turn was in contact with a chap who actually serviced this and was there when the dummy, and remember it was the Dummy only, that was removed, the cable etc in his recollection was just allowed to fall into the tunnel.... He tells me that there was a newspaper photographer and a Newsreel crew there who filmed it being disconnected and subsequently towed away. So if newsreel footage exists it will be in the NFSA archives, if it exists... BUT of course as I'm on a pension I'll have to save up to view it, if it exists. There should also be newspaper articles but I'm not adept at searching them... The ones posted above are interesting....
Ok so to up the anti what about I offer a G scale ornate traction pole? Bound to be a great conversation piece in any lounge room....

comment.author: 93255176@N07
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] b An excellent shot, now if you look to the right you will see what looks like cast Iron "U";'s That is where the cable  ran that was connected to the Dummy and obviously the centre of the tram lines. To the left AND OFF CENTRE to the actual tram lines is as we can all see the tunnel through which the Counterweight ran. Also I am reliably assured the tunnel still exists though partially filled in when the roadworks for the bus turning area was built. Access to the tunnel was via a set of steps to the Left on this pic in what was a stone wall and had a hand rail around it. Numerous anecdotes exist to eg to Yanks tried to push it down hill ( with a Jeep, WWII) but disaster struck when they changed gears and during the great depression a homeless man was said to have been in the tunnel and crushed when a tram raised the dummy...
